parts:
Here is a paper abstract:

<abstract>
Abstract
This paper proposes a theoretical framework for understanding
large language models (LLMs) through the lens of pragmatist
philosophy. The pragmatists held, usual disagreements between
participants aside, that what a thought consisted in depends not
only on some kind of causal connection with an object but also
how that thought finds space in the life of the mind (Mares, 2025).
Drawing on W.V.O. Quine's naturalized semantics, the ideas of
which are most succinctly expressed in works such as Word and
Object (1960) and "Two Dogmas of Empiricism" (1951), as well
as contributions from classical pragmatists like Charles Sanders
Peirce and John Dewey, I argue that the pragmatist approaches to
meaning and reference provide uniquely valuable insights into the
capabilities and limitations of contemporary machine learning
systems. Trying to interpret or understand LLMs through a more
orthodox lens of representational semantics I argue is doomed to
failure – the inevitable conclusion is that such systems lack the
conceptual apparatus required for "true understanding”. Ergo, it
is a category error to imagine they can ever “think” or
“understand” (semantically) in the same way that humans do.
Instead, I propose a pragmatist framework that may offer a more
productive way to conceptualize how such systems process and
generate language, this may in turn contribute positively to the
explainable AI problem (Although, I’m not much interested in
this so I’m not sure).
Quine’s holy trinity and the behaviour of LLMs.
Quine unapologetically embraced a naturalised empiricism and
semantic holism. According to which all knowledge ultimately
derives from our sense experience and observations and at the
same time is not reductive, in the sense that meaningful claims
cannot be distilled into discrete observation statements. Meaning
qua meaning is distributed by nature, "our statements about the
external world face the tribunal of sense experience not
individually but only as a corporate body" (Quine, 1951, p. 38).
Abandoning the logical positivist position that claimed that all
meaningful statements can be reduced to observation statements
with truth conditions allows for richer and more flexible semantic
interpretations. And, embracing holism allows us to see theory
(and their associated claims) as interconnected wholes rather than
discrete individual statements.
Page | 1This holistic view finds a striking parallel in how LLMs encode
semantic information across distributed parameters rather than in
discrete, localized representations. The meaning of any token in
a LLM is not tied to a specific node or parameter but emerges
from patterns of activation across the entire network. LLMs
operate without any clear distinction between syntactic pattern-
matching and semantic understanding. Their outputs emerge from
statistical regularities in vast corpora of text, with no distinction
between syntax and meaning.
Arguably Quine's most significant contribution to a what might
be a new understanding of LLMs can be found in his
indeterminacy of translation thesis. The thesis is articulated by the
famous "gavagai" thought experiment in Word and Object. Quine
argues that when confronted with a novel language, multiple
incompatible translations could fit with all the observable
evidence, with no fact of the matter about which translation is
ultimately correct. The native speaker utters “gavagai” whilst
pointing at a rabbit leaving the translator to determine the
meaning. Quine argues “rabbit” is just one of many possible
interpretations, the speaker could mean “undetached rabbit part”,
the observation that a rabbit is present at this point in time, or
something else. This indeterminacy in translation applies
profoundly in LLMs, which lack fixed referential semantics.
When an LLM generates text about "trees," there is no
determinate fact about whether it is "referring" to actual trees or
merely manipulating symbols according to learned statistical
patterns.
We can extend Quine’s indeterminacy thesis to an ontological
relativity—or a view that reference itself is relative to a
background theory or conceptual scheme. In fact, I have argued
previously that Floridi’s (2003) one-way informational
continuum suffers similar problems, whilst we can accept that the
rings of a tree convey information qua information as well
formed, meaningful data, such information subsumes knowledge
of the passing of time, seasons and the subsequent growth of trees.
For LLMs, the "ontology" is not fixed but emerges from statistical
patterns in training data. The model doesn't maintain an ontology
of distinct objects and properties in the traditional sense but
produces outputs that simulate such distinctions through
statistical regularities. This aligns with Quine's insight that "to be
is to be the value of a bound variable" (Quine, 1948, p. 15), in
LLMs, "entities" exist only insofar as they figure in the statistical
patterns the model has learned.
It is uncontroversial to state that LLMs do not understand
language through processing internal representations grounded in
the content of the word but rather through statistical patterns that
reliably generate appropriate responses to inputs. Following
Mares (2025) I take the content of a word here to mean something
that mediates between an individual’s mental representation of
that word and the thing itself, that is the thing the word is about.
Page | 2The latter connection is semantic, whereas the prior via statistical
pattern matching, is clearly not.
Quine’s naturalistic construal of semantics emphasizes
observable behavioural dispositions rather than meanings as
mental entities1. Quine’s theory of meaning is grounded in
stimulus-response patterns and dispositions to verbal behaviour,
rather than in mental representations. I hope that the analogy in
LLMs here is becoming evident. In taking this approach, we can
avoid the philosophical dead-end question of asking whether
LLMs "truly understand" language. The question becomes not
whether they possess some ineffable quality of *understanding*,
but whether their behaviour—their outputs in response to
inputs—resembles a behaviour we can merely associate with
understanding. This reframing shifts our attention from the quite
frankly silly metaphysical questions about machine
consciousness to empirical questions about their behavioural
capabilities.
By employing the ideas of Dewey and Peirce we can add further
fuel to this fire. Both emphasized language as a tool for dealing
with environments and coordinating action, rather than a
representational mirror of nature. Dewey (1925) in particular saw
language as instrumental to problem-solving. If we take an anti-
representationalist stance we can evaluate LLMs not based on
whether (or not) they somehow represent a kind of external reality
but simply whether they function as effective tools for
communication and problem-solving. If we take a utilitarian
account, we might argue that the meaning of a concept lies in its
practical consequences. In this sense we can view LLMs based on
the practical utility of their outputs rather than on metaphysical
problems around understanding, consciousness and meaning. The
measure of an LLM becomes not whether it possesses human-like
semantic representations (it doesn’t) but whether its outputs serve
human purposes effectively.
Some forty-five years before Vallor’s (2024) seminal publication
The AI Mirror, Richard Rorty's neo-pragmatist critique of
representationalism appears in Philosophy and the Mirror of
Nature (1979). Rorty's view of language as a social practice rather
than a medium of representation may shed some light on LLMs
as participants in linguistic practices rather than systems that are
required to somehow "mirror" reality. Rorty rejects a
correspondence theory of truth in favour of a view emphasizing a
very pragmatic social justification and this allows us to evaluate
LLM outputs in terms of their coherence with established
linguistic norms rather than their explicit correspondence to some
language-independent reality.
Conclusion
Incidentally this point could also be used as a counter to Floridi’s
informational ontology.
Page | 3
1And this my friends is what I call a hard-core analytic takedown
of increasing ridiculous nonsense about generative AI that is
being accepted as legitimately philosophically “debateable” these
days. More to come.
References
Dewey, J. (1925). Experience and nature. Open Court
Publishing Company.
Floridi, L. (2003). From Data to Semantic Information. Entropy
(5), 125-145.
Mares, E. (2025, March 5). AIs are mimics not semantic beings.
Newsroom. https://newsroom.co.nz/2025/03/05/ais-are-mimics-
not-semantic-beings/
Peirce, C. S. (1878). How to make our ideas clear. Popular
Science Monthly, 12, 286-302.
Quine, W.V.O. (1948). On what there is. Review of
Metaphysics, 2(5), 21-38.
Quine, W. V. (1953). Two Dogmas of Empiricism. In From a
Logical Point of View (20-46). Harvard: Harvard University
Press.
Quine, W. V. (1953). On What There Is. In From a Logical Point
of View (1). Harvard University Press.
Quine, W.V.O. (1960). Word and Object. MIT Press.
Rorty, R. (1979). Philosophy and the mirror of nature. Princeton
University Press.
Vallor, S. (2024). The AI mirror: How to reclaim our humanity
in an age of machine thinking. Oxford University Press.
Page | 4
</abstract>

Please VERY CAREFULLY and thoroughly consider:
1. what arguments are made by the paper? (Use the toulmin model to break down the arguments)
2. What evidence is used to support those arguments?
3. Please validate the citations made (all citations, each one in turn)
4. Please identify all errors, explain why they are errors, and provide well cited counter-evidence.

Discuss *only* the claims made in the paper.

Take extra time and be very careful.

To carefully analyze the arguments in this abstract and validate its citations, could you please confirm a few things:

1. Are you asking for a full fact-check and philosophical analysis of all theoretical and citation-based claims?
2. Should I focus only on the sources cited (e.g., Quine, Rorty, Dewey, etc.), or should I also investigate the validity of references to newer publications like Mares (2025) and Vallor (2024), which may be speculative or hypothetical?
3. Are you specifically interested in peer-reviewed or academic counter-evidence, or would you also like philosophical commentary and scholarly blog/publisher perspectives?

Once you confirm, I’ll proceed with detailed analysis and validation.

Confirm all sources cited. 
And I'm asking for a full argumentation breakdown of all claims.
Peer reviewed only, please

Got it. I’ll conduct a thorough analysis of the paper’s arguments using the Toulmin model, assess the supporting evidence, and verify the accuracy and legitimacy of each cited source—focusing exclusively on peer-reviewed literature. I’ll also identify any errors or unsupported claims and provide well-cited counter-evidence where applicable. I’ll update you once the full breakdown is ready.

3. Validate all citations in the paper, confirming their accuracy, peer-reviewed status, and whether the source says what the abstract claims it does. The citations to validate include:
   - Mares (2025) “AIs are mimics not semantic beings” (Newsroom)
   - Quine’s works: “Word and Object” (1960), “Two Dogmas of Empiricism” (1951), “On What There Is” (1948)
